author: @charlesvan13
text:
Firing a "warning shot" at someone is not legal.  
There are legal reasons a cop never fires a warning shot at someone.   You're either legally justified in using deadly force or not.   Firing in someone's direction is assault with a deadly weapon.   It's legal if it's self-defense, but a "warning shot" doesn't qualify.

replies.author: @charlesvan13
replies.text:
manic hispanic 
The legal situation is that you have to be justified in killing someone to fire a "warning shot".    That's why cops don't do it.   And I think if you apply for a conceal carry permit the instructor will tell you to never do it.  
It's the same reason cops don't aim for the leg.   There's no such thing as "I was shooting only to wound him" defense.   If you're shooting at someone, you're trying to kill them.

replies.author: @FaerieSeraphina
replies.text: @charlesvan13 Not to mention that it's reckless endangerment at best to discharge a firearm without first checking that it is in fact pointed at your intended target. If that round causes an injury to or worse kills a third party in those circumstances you are pretty much guaranteed to be brought up on charges for it as recklessness is sufficient mens rea for most forms of criminal assault.

replies.author: @charlesvan13
replies.text:
@FaerieSeraphina 
That Marissa Alexander case was not self-defense.   She left the house, got a gun out of her car and fired it in the direction of her ex-boyfriend.

replies.author: @charlesvan13
replies.text:
@FaerieSeraphina  
If you fire straight in the air, you're not threatening anyone. directly.   But that's also a crime because the bullet has to come down.

replies.author: @FaerieSeraphina
replies.text: @charlesvan13 As I say though even if self-defence applied reckless operation of a firearm that could potentially put third parties at risk is still not appropriate. And to be fair even firing straight up into the air is still going to screw you over as either you recklessly fired the weapon into the air without taking the time to check for air traffic including such as balloons, gliders etc that are basically silent or you are alleging that you took your eyes off a supposedly deadly threat to do so, the latter strongly calls into question how "deadly" you considered the threat to be. So either way you are either digging yourself a hole for a charge of reckless discharge of a firearm (at minimum) or digging yourself a hole by weakening your claim that deadly force was appropriate so yeah legally this it was a warning shot is a really shitty defence one way or the other.

replies.author: @LostHeretic
replies.text: @paulkiernan1852 Your first sentence makes no sense. Credibility is something gained and earned by established facts. Hence why the word credibility is used often in conjunction with a scandal or event in news media. It's a title that is stripped easily. If you make a mistake you are no longer credible. This happens all the time in the scientific community. Like the newest climate change report that the media went crazy over before they had to withdraw the report because it contradicted itself and was no longer credible. They have since released a new report that no longer has the multiple errors. They lost credibility and now anybody who questions climate science can go yeah but do you remember when X. You can be right 1000 times but if you are wrong once that is what people remember. Credibility is not some unassailable power. It's a temporary status you only keep by being very careful. Bias alone damages credibility.

"really sorry ... but columbus never set foot in Amerika"

Apperently once something exists it can't be discovered anymore. Like we discovered the mount everest, sure it had some ver old tribes living in the erea, but it still was discovered multiple time by other civilizations on later dates.

replies.text: ‚ÄãFrank Parrish So you get mad that people would like to have the option to do that? That seems pretty dumb. The reason they are so expensive is not because they are some kind of technological marvel. It's because there is only a small number of them that are legally allowed to be owned. It's supply and demand. Nothing about a full-auto AR lower makes it inherently more expensive to manufacture. It just has one extra pin and a couple of extra parts. It's the fact that there are only a small amount that are legal to own and a LOT of people who want one. And just because you have one doesn't mean you have to mag dump every time you shoot it. 50 rounds of 9mm can be had for close to $10. Hell even .223 ammo can be had for cheap if you shoot steel cased. replies.author: @jaojintalonis92
@DavidHanks90
replies.text:
@jaojintalonis92 A few things: while it is very admirable that you have served in our military and so have your relatives, that does not qualify any of you to decide that people should not have automatic weapons. 

You also have some very flawed logic here. Small arms are not the same as explosives or tanks so how exactly are those statements comparable, I am not sure. I agree that we should not have access to tanks or explosives. 

I don't think that we should just be handing them out either and that background checks should still be required to get an automatic weapon. You cannot also claim that a militia with just rifles is as effective as a militia with automatic weapons and then claim in the same paragraph that automatic weapons are much more effective against people. Which is it? Are they more or less effective? It can't be both.

The whole idea that a soldier should be allowed to have one because of the training and everything doesn't really stand either. By that same reasoning we shouldn't have any guns at all. Civilians still have to answer to any shot that is fired that shouldn't be. Unless you are shooting a target at a shooting range you better be prepared as a civilian to answer for every round you put down range and why. Having a commanding officer or not doesn't change that at all. 

And obviously if the full weight of the US military singles me out I'm gonna die in 5 seconds. But that's not what I am talking about. If they government were to turn on a the public at large or a group of people (not just some neighborhood that likes guns) they would have to deal with the fact that they are in for a long and arduous fight. Don't think so? Let's look at how effective guerrilla tactics in the Middle East have proven effective. Has the US military killed lots of them. Yup. For sure. Did we win anything. Nope. Because there a lot of them and they are still fighting.

And that is the whole point. We should have these as a further deterrent to our government becoming tyrannical. The more they take away our right to bear arms, the easier that potential fight becomes for them. It's one more check and balance in our constitution and one that I think we should take more seriously.

replies.author: @jaojintalonis92
replies.text:
@DavidHanks90 "Small arms are not the same as explosives or tanks so how exactly are those statements comparable, I am not sure." You can kill more people with an automatic weapon than a claymore mine. And the tank was to drive the point home, the regular population does not need automatic weapons just like they don't need tanks.
"Which is it? Are they more or less effective? It can't be both." They are more effective against people who are not prepared for combat and not any more effective than any other firearm against someone who is. It can be both. If you are defending yourself against a trained fighting force, they will use the same amount of caution regardless of what kind of firearm you are using, all have the potential to kill equally well. The opposing force could have any kind of expertise with the weapons they carry, but a bullet from any of them could end you.
"Having a commanding officer or not doesn't change that at all." It does because soldiers don't own automatic weapons. Soldiers don't decide when and where they use the weapons they are issued. Soldiers don't carry weapons unless they are in a training exercise, an active warzone, or an on-duty MP. The simple fact you could take your weapon out to a buddies ranch and fire a couple of shots gives you far more freedom than any military unit... you don't have to return your weapon to a superior who will count the ammunition you returned and question you when there are missing bullets, then ruin your life if you cannot answer for that ammunition.
This whole idea you have of the military singling you out and dying in 5 seconds is ludicrous. Have you never heard of a measured response? Do you think you would be overrun? Combat is not like that. A moving force needs information. A lone gunman with skill could take multiple lives before being neutralized. That is unacceptable. Tactics like that will cause significant losses and deplete morale, causing even more losses. The reason I point this out is to give you an idea that the force you would be fighting would not be blindly walking into an ambush or stampeding across your home like a charging rhino. They will be cautious and wary, they will spend time gathering intel before moving. The weapon you are using is a footnote to things like: troop position, chokes, areas with cover, sniper vantages, fortified defenses. Not to mention, guerrilla warfare is more effective when the guerrilla's know more about the terrain than the trespassers. US Soldiers were not born in Afghanistan, if they were, you would see even fewer casualties. If, heaven forbid, they were called to fight a war on US soil; they can be as familiar with the area as you are and will probably have much better intel. As an example: the AK-47 is superior to the M5 in practically every conceivable way, yet the losses for the US are much smaller, and the Viet-Cong were so poorly equipped that some fought with nothing more than sharpened sticks... and they won that war.

Military over use is a natural conclusion of the repression of rights- something that does not happen instantly, but rather in small pieces over the course of decades if not centuries. 

I absolutely do want to live in a society where the combined power of the people is greater than that of the government. 

I also would like to point out that I am not a right winger, I am much more of a centrist- I don‚Äôt want you to misinterpret what I‚Äôm about to say next as being the ravings of a fanatic. 

What f***ing country are you from my man? Did you read anything about the American revolution? Do you understand why we have a f***ing constitution? It was because the government willfully violated the rights of its citizens. 

Laws were passed to ensure that would never happen again ( Bill of rights ), the second one was the right to bear arms. The first one was freedom of speech and religion and petition, and it carries no weight without the second.  

We are NOT a democracy. We are a representative republic which has a very specific series of checks and balances built into it to ensure that no one group of government ever gets power over the others, and that the government itself can never take power over from the states, and subsequently from the individuals

The entire purpose of the way that our constitution is structured is to maintain a balance of power, and if your federal government has a monopoly of that for us it will absolutely abuse it

That is a lesson that history has taught us and not some instances, but in every instance where the government has had a monopoly of power, abuse is a natural result. 

Again, I do not want you to think that I am some far flung right wing nut job, I am a very progressive person in my politics, but one thing I will never, ever buy John, is reducing the power of the bill of rights, the power of the individual, the power of the individual versus the power of the government.

replies.author: @paulkiernan1852
replies.text:
@jatbatman I think you misunderstood what Freud was saying. He was saying that our base instinct of wanting to be partners with a female comes from having a mother in the first place. Humans normally don't have sexual tendencies until puberty, and by then your brain understands the difference between family and non-family. He took his research waay waay too far to figure this out, but to some extent makes sense. If you're an atheist or an agnostic it makes some sense that you get your innate desire for females as a male from being with your mother. That's why you see a lot of people who will marry someone who is similar to the parent of the opposite gender, NOT ALWAYS, but a lot of the time you'll see similarities. It is also where you learn that kissing someone is intimate and a way to show someone you love them, and also that you hold hands with someone you care for. So yes, Sigmund Freud had and still does have a lot of credibility. But using a psychologist isn't the same thing as stating facts. Psychology is never 100% on one side or the either, there are and always will be outlying factors that change your results in a study. Having a study about people is one thing, but statistics themselves about anything else are hardly ever wrong, mainly because of the use of the scientific method. 

For example, the amount of people killed by police is a sure thing that happened in the past, where no matter what the statistics will NOT CHANGE, but a study on mental health is a study that deals with the human body, which constantly changes and evolves, and does so differently depending on the person, which will result in statistics that are completely correct in the situation and controlled environment you do the test in, but will have altered results if you do it anywhere else.

replies.text:
@jatbatman Thank you, for once someone actually realized that most of what I do say when debating with someone uses logic and not only just opinions. 

When I was in high school I took psychology 3 times before I graduated because I loved the teacher, and I took it again in college where they actually went more in depth about freud's studies. Plus, my senior year I took a philosophy class where we were taught to take anything anyone says, sarcastic or not, and make a rebuttal using logic, because using sarcasm back will only result in each person not knowing whether the person they are debating is taking the debate seriously or not. 

I just wish that other people in these comments would actually try to have a debate instead of telling me that he is skewing his facts or that his facts are false then not showing or saying anything to back it up. No examples, nothing. I think some people see something that they have felt was true for so long, then see someone say that what they thought was true really wasn't, then go into denial and refuse to actually talk about it. 

My favorite episode of Adam Ruins Everything actually explains this really well. Take the time to watch his episode on conspiracy theories, it actually goes into why they are damaging to the thought process of everyone. The best part is when he pulls in a psychologist to explain why people refuse to change their opinions, despite there being facts obviously saying that they are wrong. She says that it's because when you bombard someone like that with facts, they start to feel attacked personally, and will fight you regardless of whether what they are saying makes sense or not. I feel that this is why there is no progress happening with the gun debate in america. Nobody tries to even bother looking at the other side and realizing that maybe some of what they are saying is true, and picking out the things that aren't, they just immediately think that everything they are saying is false.

replies.author: @GallantGunsmith
replies.text:
@tylerdurden7690 Hi, also a gun owner here, come to help you with your understanding on a basic background check and the more intense background checks that are being proposed.

Now, for some frame of reference, the United States is considered a First world Developed Nation, like most of Europe, Japan, and a few other counties. Now, compared to some of those other countries, we are practically giving away fire arms away to anyone that wants one. Japan, for instance, has an extremely rigorous process where any sort of red flag that pops up immediately stops the process and you are labeled ineligible to own a fire arm. And in Switzerland, if you have previously broken any law, even a minor one, you are also considered ineligible to possess a fire arm because it is considered that since you can't follow a simple law, then the ones around fire arms are way too complicated for you. 

Now, in regards with Backgrounds checks, I'm actually going to talk about my current job in retail. Now, I work at a corporate drug store, and part of the job (and being a cashier) is that we will have customers come in the buy cigarettes. No big deal. But part of the state laws of where I live and work, we have to look at the ID of everyone, regardless of how old they look. And have to check every time they come in, even if they are a regular, of a cclose friend. We also have to make sure that the ID is valid. If it's expired, it cannot be accepted. 

Now, all of that is important to set the premise of how I'm going to talk about background checks. Imagine what I said to buy cigarettes in my state is the base form of background checks that every gun owners have to go through when buying a fire arm. Sure it is a bit inconvenient, but it's something that is required, and if everything checks out, you are fine and can go about your business. Now for more detailed background checks, I see that similar as me asking for a second legitimate ID to make sure that the person is exactly who they say they are. With bother forms being up to date. If the information on the ID doesn't match, then I can with call my supervisor, or outright deny you sale. That's essentially what the more detailed background checks are. And if you are a law abiding citizen who has all the proper paperwork in order, you have nothing to worry about. But if you make a big fuss about the process, it will be seen with some scrutiny, because red flags will start going up. 

Part of this issue that also needs to be handled is interpersonal gifting of fire arms between family members and the selling at Gun/Hunting-Fishing shows. In both situations there HAS to be the same level of checks or at least paperwork that needs to be done so as to keep things consistent. If you are against that, then I propose that the original owner should be punished for any crimes committed with the fire arm. Similarly to how a car works. If you gift your cousin a firearm for their birthday and they went and shot up a school with that firearm, then you are held equally responsible. 

There are a lot more points we can talk about, including the new law that is going through in NY regarding concealed carry permits. But I think I got my main point across.

replies.author: @GallantGunsmith
replies.text:
@whoeverelse Thank you. I'm all for fire arm ownership,I agree on the right for it, and that it is also just fun to have. But I also do take into account that it is infact a dangerous weapon, and that we do need simple and reasonable legislation put through to make sure that everyone who receives a fire arm will not be a danger to society as a whole. As discriminatory as this may sound, I am very against people with certain mental disabilities being allowed to own fire arms, my partner works in special ed, and from what i have heard, some of the people there should be anywhere near anything sharp, let alone a fire arm. 

I just want everyone to be safe, and while we are very often told that this right is meant to keep us safe, I do believe it needs to be revised and restructured to match with modern time. Remember, when the 2nd Amendment was written, Rifled Barrels were still a relatively new uncommon technology.

replies.author: @whoeverelse
replies.text: @GallantGunsmith I do believe it should be slightly reworded, to update the language.  The term Militia went through several changes as well as being regulated in itself. I believe something more or less turning Militia into "the people" and updating "regulated" to the provisions immediately legislated with it would suffice. No large changes, just terminology updates more aligning with the original framing without the centuries of legislation changing and defining terms. The only thing I see it really guaranteeing is readily available for people 18-36(I may be wrong on the upper age). Which is something that licensing and training prior to ownership do get in the way of. However, in todays day where people are seemingly more readily violent than ever (population size may skew this a little), we should have a bare requirement for handling on public property.  I do believe the mental health issues should be tackled prior to anything and not just limited to mental disabilities.

replies.author: @Slomowo
replies.text:
Now that I'm back from work, will also refer to the statistics surrounding the suicide case. It would be useless to talk specifically about suicide by gun, since it makes no point; of course states with a higher gun ownership will have a higher suicide by gun rate. If you don't have a gun, you won't commit suicide with one; if a whole population has less guns, they're less likely to commit suicide with guns. What matters is the effect that guns have on suicide rate as a whole.

And the answer is that gun ownership does seem to affect suicide rates greatly, although there are some exceptions to the correlation. Of the top 15 states in overall suicide rates, not a single one has a gun ownership lower than 30%. Of the bottom 15 states in overall suicide rates, only one has high gun ownership (Mississipi, with gun ownership of 55.3%), and other 5 have gun ownership higher than 30%. All the bottom 5 states in overall suicide rates have low or very low gun ownership (excluding D.C., but D.C. has the lowest suicide rate *and* the lowest gun ownership, but the highest gun murder rate, as we've seen before).

This means that there is a clear correlation between gun ownership and suicide rate, but it seems there is a way to get around it becoming very problematic (Mississipi, Minnesota, Virginia, Nebraska, North Carolina, Texas). Much like the case of gun murder rate, there are many other variables not being taken into account besides gun ownership and firearm laws.

Still, we cannot ignore the fact that suicide becomes a huge problem when gun ownership rises.

replies.author: @nickdahl203
replies.text:
@pashlyn We don't live in that era? Well shit, better tell Adam that. He seems to think, along with the rest of his far left ilk, that anybody whose skin is darker than Khaki is basically doomed.

Are we assuming the boyfriend in question would, if given access to a weapon, murder his ex? If so, why is this violent lunatic allowed in public where he could still acquire knives, or an ax, or a book of matches, and kill his ex in some way that doesn't involve a firearm? It seems a strange omission to be concerned about one weapon while still leaving access to every other conceivable weapon in existence, including rocks and pointy sticks. To paraphrase Archie Bunker, would you prefer thy were pushed out of windows? Treat him like the criminals above. Can he be trusted out in public to not kill people? Yes? What's the problem? No? Why is he out in public?

How would you effectively close the gun show loophole? What, precisely, stops me from selling my gun to some random guy? As for the ''without a background check'', you know at some point somebody had to get said background check done before the gun was handed over, right? While the final owner may not be on record, the FFL that bought it from the manufacturer would be, and they would have a record of who they sold the gun to, at which point the investigation can commence.

A national and searchable database of gun owners? Why? To what end? I'd rather people not know where I live and what valuables I keep. Should we also let it be publicly known what hours I'm not home, and the combination to my safe? Do my 4th amendment rights to  security of my personal effects mean nothing?

The CDC published a study about gun violence in 2013. ''PRIORITIES FOR RESEARCH TO REDUCE THE THREAT OF FIREARM-RELATED VIOLENCE''. So that's one stricken from the list already. 

It would be a good think to not open the kettle of worms that is proscribing what mental illnesses prevent one from owning a gun. Namely, if a judge were to crack open a copy of the DSM5, and flip to the entry on Gender Dysphoria, and poof, no firearms rights for transsexuals. Oh, what a shit storm that would stir.

The problem is, what you ask for doesn't just cut into 2nd amendment rights, but 1st, 4th, and 5th, and 14th as well. Do I have a right to association and assembly? Or am I not allowed to meet like winded people at a convention and trade items? Items in this instance being Constitutionally protected firearms. 

Do I have a right to privacy and security of my house, person, documents, and effects, or must those things be accessible at all times to government, and possibly public, inquest, due to my ownership of a firearm? What you propose sounds like treating gun owners the same way as we treat convicted sex offenders. Only it would double as a shopping list for criminals looking for free guns, if this list is publicly accessible.

Which brings me to the 5th. Proposing to strip me of the previous aforementioned rights, without due process or trial, because I own a firearm. 

And that violates the Equal Protection clause of the 14th amendment, because you propose to treat certain citizens, about 1/3 of them, differently, due to the free exercise of certain rights.

replies.author: @pashlyn
replies.text:
@nickdahl203  So I'm on my phone right now so I can't say and do everything I want but here goes. Also a small correction, I didn't say we live in an era I said I(me, the person writing this) wasn't in era. Also I don't think it's useful to use the Adam Conover character to inform your opinions on Adam Conover the person.

So I wanna start on a point of agreement, when I said I want a national and searchable database of gun owners and their guns I was vauge and you had every right to call me out on it. What I should've said said was I want a searchable database of guns and gun owners by law enforcement because the system right now feels like it's riddled with holes. Also I don't know if I bought it up but I want compulsory gun registration. At the very least I hope we can agree that if a firearm is stolen or sold it would be useful for the police to be able to put a serial number to face or name (small point: I don't know why someone would knowingly try to rob someone they know has a gun(s) seems kinda high risk/low reward imo).

My original plan was to go through your post and to explain or clarify or offer some middle ground to points you bought up but than you kinda just didn't do that. Like when I bought up the boyfriend loophole you could've said something like "Well most victims of abuse don't always report their abuser or go on the recant later or charges are never filed in the first place" we could've gone from there but you didn't and for some reason you bought up knives and axes(?) like yeah, my dude, people can use those things to hurt and kill people but they can also not be used for those reasons while a gun is a tool designed expressly to kill someone/thing as quickly as easily as possible. Same with the gun show loophole I offer a solution (not a perfect one I'll admit) but it's a step towards hopefully stopping, or at least tracking grey area gun deals better. Maybe we could make background checks cheaper or offer some kind of incentive for private seller to preform background checks or even making big red flag information available quickly instead of waiting for the entire report. I don't know shit about the FFL and I'm too tired/lazy to look it up so I'll just cede the point.

As for the 2013 CDC study you're talking about fun fact: the first thing that came up about the study was a 2015 article by the Washington Post titled "The study that gun-rights activists keep citing but completely misunderstand" so I thought that was cute. Also it feels like you're kinda leaving out that for about 16 years up until that point the CDC was barred from doing studies into gun violence and it took, through executive order, for even that study to be conducted says there need to be more studies into gun violence. The Dickey Amendment, which is still on the books, basically makes it so they have to word their studies very carefully so they aren't used to "promote or advocate for gun control". They can study gun violence but they also can't because if they slip up that could be their careers so no one will risk it. I want the CDC, which is banned from doing studies into gun violence, to be able to do studies into gun violence.

I don't know what's going on here. I specifically ignored talking about mental illness because I didn't want to open that "kettle of worms (da faq?) but for some reason you go there and you use trans people and gender dysphoria which is hilarious cause I follow a ton of trans people and have the internet so I can say that gender dysphoria isn't a mental illness. It can, however lead to lower mental health because of the stress and anxiety it causes but it seems like it goes away once the person acknowledges they are trans and, if they decide, take the steps to transition.

So this part you say i cut into your 1st, 2nd, 4th, 5th, and 14th amendment rights but am I thought? So as I can see 1st and 2nd amendment, right to free speech, right to peaceful assembly, and the right to keep and bear arms and a well regulated militia which, while I'm not super down with, I'm ok with. Like my idea of it is that it's a bunch of local dude bros who get together and patrol their neighborhood and are like real into gun safety and offer to teach the new gun owners how to handle themselves in a relaxed setting like an open field or something and the police know them and maybe do like weekly/monthly check in to see if everything is going alright and offer assistance if something happens. I mean why would I or anyone care that you and your buds are talking about guns or going to a convention with guns IDGAF. The 4th... don't know why you bought it up since nothing I said directly affects them, as far as I can see, unless you committed a crime than, according to your 5th amendment you would be entitled to a trial and if found guilty you would probably be stripped of your gun so.. I guess I'm ok with that.

Lastly I don't know why you bought up sex offenders in regards to gun ownership but yeah I'm ok with them not having guns either provided they aren't the really bad sex offenders. I guess lastly the 14th amendment, which I feel like I covered when I was talking about the fifth but then you say about 1/3 of Americans have guns and according to a Pew Research study in 2017 77% of gun owners are in favor of background checks at gun shows, 54% are in favor of catching a federal database for tracking gun sales and 82% are in ok with not selling guns to people on the no-fly/watch lists. I'll say this again are not "perfect" or "good", I'm a very pie in the sky type of guy, but they are, to me, a step in a direction we could take or completely dismiss and try something different but going through your response to mine it doesn't really feel you want to do much as be right but for me to just be wrong. You bring up a lot of whataboutisms and deflections that don't really matter to the argument at hand and I have to wonder, did you really care or are you just being a troll? (small edit: after i thought about it a bit I felt bad about calling you a troll and I changed my mind I don't think you are a troll, I just think you're a centrist).

replies.text:
@pashlyn And YouTube ate my comment. Great. A point by point response, gone. 

Suffice to say, I don't think you understood a lot of my points, especially when I brought up a determined abuser would just use a different method other than a gun, and you accused me of deflection and whataboutism when that was exactly what you did when I showed you the CDC study on gun violence, and never once acknowledge that you actually got what you wanted, only complained that you didn't get it sooner 

You keep advocating for things that would have horrible repercussions. Like opening up the NICS system to everybody. You admit you don't know how FFL works, so you wouldn't know this, but the NICS system contains a great deal of privileged information, including social security numbers. Allowing literally anybody to put in a name and receive such information would be immediately abused.

I know you want to do "something", but I would rather we do nothing rather than make a mistake which would only make things worse.

replies.author: @pashlyn
@nickdahl203
replies.text:
@pashlyn '' Its clear that you just interested in arguing in bad faith''

Oh bullshit, you're just getting BTFO'd and are butthurt. I've been arguing in nothing but the best faith I can provide you.

'' responding to you is just a massive waste of what little time I have on this earth and its getting either of us nowhere. ''

And yet there's 3 paragraphs here.

'' I say doing "something" is better than doing nothing ''

And that is objectively false, because making things worse is not better than doing nothing.

'' you say you'd rather nothing get done because of a chance that mistakes would be made ''

No, I'm saying you need to be careful you don't throw the baby out with the bathwater, and pointing out the obvious flaws in what you want.

'' and I say if we don't make these small mistakes now, while we can control them and course correct'

That is assuming the mistakes are small, and can be controlled and corrected. 

''then later, when lets say something major happens and congress pushes through a rushed bill of some kind, a lot of innocent people could be caught up in the cross fire.''

That is exactly what you are doing now, advocating Congress push through a rushed bill, that they ''do something'', and a lot of people get caught up in the cross fire. I am warning you that you are walking into the very thing you don't want.

''You seem to have made another mistake reading what I wrote because in my last reply I agreed with you that having database of guns searchable by anyone was a bad idea and changed to a federal database, specifically for police and government agent types.''

You also wanted universal access to the Background check system, the NICS. In order for this to work, by necessity, that federal database would need to be accessible by all, so that universal background checks could even be possible. It's not a mistake in reading, you just don't know what it really is you're asking for.

'' I mentioned I didn't give a shit about FFL and I'm still to tired to look it up''

No, you said you didn't *know* shit about it. Not that you didn't care. Why are you using your ignorance and laziness as an argument, and then changing your argument as if I can't just scroll up and read what you *actually* said?

'' but I did glance at NICS and it seems like it only really works if the gun has been reported stolen or sold. I say you should read this Quora page its not like a government study or anything its just interesting''

<smacks forehead>
That's the NCIC, you moron! Those are entirely different databases! The NICS is the National Instant Checking System that performs background checks, the NCIC is the National Crime Information Center. How do you fuck that up? 

'' You say I never understand or acknowledge your points''

And nothing has proven this more than just fucking now, where you are so pig ignorant on a subject you cite me a completely different database.

'' I keep having to ask, what points?''

That what you want will violate far, far more human rights than anybody should be comfortable with, and that you don't actually know what the fuck you're talking about.

'' You never bring up any alternatives solutions to anything I say''

Solutions to *what*? You keep using vague terms to proscribe that there is a problem to solve, but unless I've missed something, you haven't actually stated the specific problem you want solved.

''you aren't willing to offer any sort of compromise either. ''

Why should I compromise? Hey, you owe me $10,000. What's that? You owe me nothing? Well, how about we compromise, you pay me half, and we call it good. What? You are unwilling to compromise? What a terrible person you are!

''It feels like I'm putting in all the work in this relationship ''

Work? Relationship? Your first response to me was basically being an asshole while I tried to be as reasonable as possible so we could even converse, and now you're getting bitchy because of whatever this Carl guy did to get you booty bothered.

'' and you're just finger wagging behind me going "No no no we musn't do that" ''

And? You're saying things that are factually incorrect. You claim the CDC cannot do research in gun violence, despite me telling you the exact name of their published findings, and you confuse the NCIC for the NICS. If it seems like I'm being condescending, it's because you keep being obviously wrong, and arrogant at the same time.

''all the while resorting to whataboutisms''

Where? Cite an example, please.

'' and slippy slope fallacies. ''

The slippery slope is a legitimate argument, it's only a fallacy if the slope in question cannot be shown to exist. Also, where did I even use this argument?

''This is goodbye''

Let's see if you can let me get in the last word, or if I can prove you a liar.

'' try to write your posts in notepad first so next time you don't lose your scathing reply. ''

It wasn't even scathing, it was explanatory. Again, I've been trying to do this in best faith, but it seems like I'm dealing with the Dunning Kreuger king, who calls all who disagree with him liars and trolls.

Im adding another Condition to the Economic Breakdown i asked for earlier. We still dont care what poeple think, but we also will not have children. Assume we're Sterile or whatever.

As for "equity", remember that Value in the Home Market is one of the first things to Tank in a economic downturn. Your whole neighborhood is worthless if the pricw of living in the surrounding area drives everyone away.

If that happens your forced to move, before your equity is actually worthless, but a renting situation carries no such risk.

Basically Owning something is a Commitment, and in todays economy, Commiting to something is NOT the Smartest Play.  

Youve got what, 10 years before we're past the point of no return with Global Warming? How many Years before any number of Trumps Economic Executive Orders possibly come into Question? 

Look, i get that Buying a Home is part of the American Dream, and im sure it all sounds great on paper. 

But the world is not and never has been that simple. Its smarter to remain as uncommitted as you can, so that when the chips fall, you arent crushed under them.

One of the biggest problems right now is that people can't admit when they are wrong. And a related issue is that we, the general populace, only want to trust people we view as infallible or always correct. Someone that admits they made a mistake suddenly loses all credibility. . even though anyone can make a mistake. We're all human.

replies.author: @Mahbu
replies.text:
See, you're making some very bold - and dubious - assumptions here. 

"Fear of being called racist" is a very poor excuse, you must realize. And sounds awfully suspicious. You say they can't investigate or they risk being called racist? That's pretty much because police departments have a long and sordid history of BEING racist. You might dismiss this but I should remind you Stop and Frisk targeted almost entirely minorities. . . and yet failed to produce any serious results. I should also point out that police departments have been caught red headed with quotas, with secret programs that target African Americans, and with members who express views that would make the KKK or Neo Nazis proud. Not one offs, I should say. Hell, a paramedic was recently identified as someone who ran a hate podcast where he described minorities as 'animals'.

I'd also direct you to the numerous recent cases where black people have been killed for next to no reason. The guy that stopped the potential mass shooter? SOMEONE THE NRA SHOULD'VE STOOD UP FOR BUT DIDN'T. . . Shot and killed by the police The guy sitting in his own home? Shot and killed by a police officer. .  whose department quickly pointed out there was weed in his house. This is a theme, by the way. . that police departments will highlight any negative of the black person shot while glamorizing the cop that shot them. . which I understand but it's still a dick move. Oh. And they love changing their stories. A lot. What about the little kid with the toy gun in the store? I've done that. I've NEVER had to worry about being shot. 

And before you say it, no, running and failure to immediately complying are not good excuses to shoot or kill someone. They're not. Especially in the circumstances that cops often do it with minorities. Fight, flight, or freeze is a powerful biological response to situations like these and people people panic. In the case of SWAT accidentally breaking into the wrong house or confronting people. . an instance where white people actually do stand a good chance of being shot. . people are uncooperative because they are disorientated, confused, and can't hear what the fuck is being said. Couple that with the fact that the odds of dying in a confrontation with police are higher for black people. . of course they are going to panic.

There was a neat little video I was watching that explained once upon a time police were asked to access a situation first. If they did this, a lot of lives would be spared.

So you ask me what police can do? They can do that. Maybe have some patience first. Better training. We argue back and forth about militarization but, really, if they are going to act like soldiers they may as well be trained like them. Troops typically have stricter ROE and restrain themselves accordingly.

Another solution would be doing something about poverty. Poverty causes crime. I can go into Red Lining with you and other racist policies that shaped the US over the last century or two. . . but I suspect you already have a full plate.

replies.author: @Mahbu
replies.text:
Hm, I see. I had a small suspicion. It's all right.

But that is the question, isn't it? It's not an easy one otherwise we would've fixed it already.

The first step is to recognize communities see the police differently. Growing up, I never feared the police. I thought the police were cool. Still do. Have many police buddies. But my friends of other ethnic backgrounds, especially Latino and African american or Caribbean descent, have a deep distrust of authority based on historical systemic and institutionalized racism.

Have you seen the videos featuring white people calling police on black people for no apparent good reason? It seems like it's a sudden and new trend but, here's the surprise. . it's not. This has been going on for a long time. It's just that now people are willing to do something about it and also people recognize the power of technology to capture those moments and share them instantly.

The shootings of minorities or innocent civilians? IE wrongful deaths? It's no big secret that they intentionally keep those records murky or poorly kept. Needless to say it's not a new phenomena; it's just being reported more and more.

Going back to stop and frisk, it doesn't sound like a bad idea to people like you or I because we aren't impacted by it. On the surface it sounds great until you realize deep down inside you don't expect yourself to be stopped and frisked. And chances are you won't be. I won't be. Police will probably ignore us or wave.  Now consider the studies done that show overwhelmingly minorities were targeted and overwhelmingly the searches showed negative. It shows that A.) the measure was used to disproportionately target minorities and B.) was ineffective at the task it was designed to do. 

Really, police may not be the solution. . just. . a bandaid.

The problem with crime is it's intrinsically linked with poverty and lack of opportunity. If we can tackle those issues, uplift communities and provide opportunities. . crime goes down. All police will have to do is be present, patrol, and respond.

text: I would say reasonable suspicion if a stop involves a motor vehicle. It's probable cause, a higher standard, if you are on foot. Generally, car stops are allowed to be more intrusive. As a prosecutor, we were taught to compare probable cause to more likely than not that someone did, was commiting or was about to commit a crime.

author: @PlasmaFuzer
text:
Excellent analysis and refutation.  When I first saw Adam Ruins everything, it was about some innocuous issue and I thought the idea of the show was actually pretty interesting (also some of the visuals are actually pretty humorous, like the "Black Panther" riding in the toy Jeep in this episode for instance).  However in the second episode about the Electoral College, I immediately recognized a pretty significant political bias based in, as your correctly identified, how the issue of the episode is initially framed.  While the creators of the show would no doubt defend their choice of framing on the basis of "artistic licence," it is always in my opinion the most simplistic and politically expedient framing in which to create a straw-man in order to demagogue the issue.  

Unfortunately too many people take these types of superficially "researched" content as gospel, and fail to exercise any critical thinking whatsoever.  This is probably due to a lack of basic understanding or knowledge about the issue, which can be used to identify discrepancies which warrant further research on their own.

The grounds for terry v Ohio is not that cut and dry. You can‚Äôt just frisk someone becuase they committed a crime.
